title: New font- feedback needed
content:
Hi everybody,  
Im a brand new user and Im completing a week of work experience at Emerystudio, this morning I was given a student brief to design a logo for an apartment development and I went a little of the track and design a new typeface from some pen doodles that i did when I was bored,  
this is the first version, all done in Illustrator, Id love some feedback so that I can develop it in font lab and use it for a 3rd folio piece ( Im studying Visual Communication at MONASH)

sorry for the image low quality

Thanks!

melanie yencken

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150111231810im_/http:/typophile.com/files/111Barkly-linefont_6434.jpg)
author: melanieyencken

comments.content: This is pretty fun. The middle of the w might come higher. The 8 doesn't work for me. The k is tricky, it is working less well than the x & v. What do you think of it?

I love this! I agree with Eben about the W. I also think the 1 is too similar to a 9. It would take the context for me to tell what it was. Also could the Y have a double line at the bottom? But I think this is really terrific and quite original. I can see this being a success with a bit of work!
I cant see your fonts .. Am I doing something wrong ?

This is interesting. It has potential for some cool alternate characters, not to mention the ligature possibilities. Also, a lower case 'w' has to have a center stroke that partially meets the x-height in order to look balanced, same goes for an uppercase 'W'. On some rare occasions this not true.

I understand that this is a mock up, but with such a simple approach to a typeface, i.e. grid bound, you have to follow the rules of the grid and create characters with consistent themes and "color". Some of the most simple typefaces are the most meticulous. Look at Wim Crouwel's faces for example.

Lastly, I would try making the diagonal strokes on the 'k, v, w & x' meet flush with the x-height, that is have them be squared off on the ends.

Great Job, looks cool.

I like this - it's a good idea for an apartment development, it has an architectural quality that also puts me in mind of Piet Mondrian. I could envisage that on the side of a building in sheet steel of maybe 1 cm thick by 15 cm deep.

With a bit of refinement here and there it would look great. Make the n, u and y the same width as the b, d, g, o, p, and q. I'm sure you can sort the rest yourself.

Nick Cooke

<cite>it has an architectural quality that also puts me in mind of Piet Mondrian</cite>

Wouldn't it be more of Theo van Doesburg since he's got diagonals?

Back to the design, I could also see the r with a horizontal instead of vertical double. Or, I suppose, you could put in some alt characters, there are lots of options with what you've got. (and am I the only one with this odd desire for a complement font made of swirls based on the current one?)

_«El futuro es una línea tan fina que apenas nos damos cuenta de pintarla nosotros mismos». (La Luz Oscura, por Javier Guerrero)_

\> I cant see your fonts .. Am I doing something wrong ?

Ah! I couldn't see it either. It's a browser thing. The image doesn't show for me in Firefox, but I see it in Safari.

<cite> I could also see the r with a horizontal instead of vertical double </cite>

This is a good point. But I would ad a knob to the arm of the r and instead make the crossbar of the t double.

Many of the problems in your design won't emerge to you until you start setting things in it.
if it's a JPG image, please re-upload it as an RGB file.

I had to look on Safari also.

Love the font. Let us know when it is for sale. :-)

Sharon
You're going to miss out on everyone's comments who is either using IE or Firefox (unless you change you're attachment spec).
I would love to see each character made from a single stroke.

I wouldn't change a thing, "don't let them pollute your mind".  
In the other hand, did you consider the case that if used in small sizes (10, 12...pt) the lines would actually disappear.

I love it.

Cheers!
